arm_group.description: microcirculation after cardiac arrest by SDF and NIRS, in patients treated with 36 degrees
microcirculation after cardiac arrest by SDF and NIRS, in patients treated with 33 degrees

brief_summary.textblock:
The hypothesis is: In patients after an out of hospital cardiac arrest, treated with
      therapeutic hypothermia (33°C) will be found significantly more microcirculatory
      abnormalities, compared to the same group of patients treated with 36°C.

clinical_study.brief_title: Microcirculatory Perfusion in Patients With Coma After Out-of-hospital Cardiac Arrest

detailed_description.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to investigate the (sublingual) microcirculation in patients
      after an out of hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA). The microcirculation is measured in this
      study by Sublingual Side Stream Darkfield (SDF) Imaging and Near InfraRed Spectroscopy
      (NIRS) at admission and after 12 and 24 hours.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  out-of-hospital cardiac arrest

          -  > 18 years

          -  informed consent

          -  ROSC (return of spontaneous circulation) < 4 hours

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  recent maxillofacial surgery

          -  participation in other clinical trials

study_pop.textblock: patients after out of hospital cardiac arrest

intervention.description: at baseline, after 12 and 24 hours in both arms
intervention.intervention_name: microcirculation by SDF and NIRS, in 33 and 36 degrees
other_name: measurements of the microcirculation by SDF and NIRS

clinical_study.official_title: Microcirculatory Perfusion as Measured by Sublingual SDF Imaging and NIRS in Patients With Coma After Out-of-hospital Cardiac Arrest Treated With Mild Therapeutic Hypothermia (TH) or Not Treated With Mild-TH

oversight_info.authority: Netherlands: The Central Committee on Research Involving Human Subjects (CCMO)

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
